questions.text: A 35-year-old woman experienced severe abdominal pain with hypotension and shock that led to her death within 36 hours after onset of the pain. From the gross appearance of the mesentery, which of the following events has most likely occurred?
questions.solution:
D. Image shows the areas of white chalky deposits represent foci of fat necrosis with calcium soap formation (saponification) at the sites of lipid breakdown in the mesentery.

  • It results from the release of pancreatic lipases in a patient with acute pancreatitis.

  1. Viral hepatitis does not cause necrosis in other organs and hepatocyte necrosis from viral infections occurs mainly by means of apoptosis.
  2. Tuberculosis produces caseous necrosis.
  3. Intestinal infarction is a form of coagulative necrosis.

REFERENCE: ROBBINS & COTRAN pathologic basics of disease, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NUMBER. 41.

questions.text:
Flow cytometry of a blood from a patient is as below:

What is likely to be the leading cause of disease-related death in this individual?
questions.solution:
1. Shown flow cytometry is from a patient with paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria(PNH).
    • It shows a population of red cell (RED DOTS) that is deficient in both CD55 and CD59.
    • As is typical of PNH, a second population (BLACK DOTS) CD55+, CD59+ that is derived from residual normal hematopoietic stem cells also present.
    • PNH is a rare hematological disorder characterized by the absence of CD55 and CD59 on granulocytes and other blood cells.
    • CD55 and CD59 are complement regulatory proteins that protect cells from complement-mediated lysis.
    • Flow cytometry is used to detect the absence of CD55 and CD59 on granulocytes and other blood cells, which is diagnostic of PNH.
    • PNH patients are at increased risk of venous thrombosis due to the absence of CD55 and CD59, which regulate complement activation.
  2. Arterial thrombosis is less common in PNH.
  3. Hemorrhage is not directly related to PNH.
  4. Infections are not a primary complication of PNH.

REFERENCE: ROBBINS & COTRAN pathologic basics of disease, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NUMBER. 649.

questions.text:
60-year-old man presents with fatigue and weakness. Bone marrow aspirate as below:

Which stain is used for this?
questions.solution:
D. Shown image Prussian Blue iron stain on marrow aspirate from a patient with refractory anemia with ringed sideroblasts and thrombocytosis is shown. Numerous ringed sideroblasts are noted.

Perls' Prussian blue stain is used to detect iron accumulation in the mitochondria of erythroblasts, characteristic of ringed sideroblasts in sideroblastic anemia.

  1. Reticulin stain - evaluates bone marrow fibrosis.
  2. Trichrome stain - detects collagen fibers and bone marrow fibrosis.
  3. Giemsa stain - used for bone marrow aspirate smears to evaluate cell morphology.

REFERENCE: ESSENTIALS OF HAEMATOLOGY KAWTHALKAR, 2nd EDITION, PAGE NUMBER. 112.

choices.text: Mutation in the UBE3A gene (maternal allele)

questions.text:
A 3-year-old child with ataxic gait, developmental delay, frequent smiling and laughter. Genetic Diagrammatic representation of this child is as below:

Which of the following is a common genetic basis for this?
questions.solution:
Patient's symptoms and a diagrammatic representation suggest ANGELMAN SYNDROME.

  • Angelman Syndrome is typically caused by a deletion of the maternal allele of chromosome 15q11-q13, which includes the UBE3A gene.
  • The paternal allele is normally imprinted and silenced.
  • In small minority (1% to 4%) of patients, there is an imprinting defect.

REFERENCE: ROBBINS & COTRAN pathologic basics of disease, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NUMBER. 179.

questions.text: Which genetic disorder is most likely to cause by following mode of inheritance?
questions.solution:
• Shown pedigree chart is of mitochondrial inheritance.
  • Note that all offspring of affected female manifest disease while all offspring of affected male are normal.

OPtion B: Leber hereditary optic neuropathy is a disorder caused by mutation in mitochondrial DNA.

Option A: Marfan syndrome - Autosomal dominant

Option C: Wilson disease - Autosomal recessive

Option D: Lesch Nyhan syndrome - X linked recessive

REFERENCE: ROBBINS & COTRAN pathologic basics of disease, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NUMBER. 178.

questions.text: Which type of lesion is this?
questions.solution:
• Picture is of hyperplastic renal arteriole.
  • This is a type of arteriolosclerosis involving a narrowed
  • The term "onion-skin" is sometimes used to describe this form of blood vessel with thickened concentric smooth muscle cell layer and thickened, reduplicated basement membrane.
  • In malignant hypertensionthese hyperplastic changes are often accompanied by fibrinoid deposits and vessel wall necrosis (necrotizing arteriolitis), particularly in kidney.

Option D: Hyaline Arteriolosclerosis: Characterized by hyaline deposits in the arteriolar wall, often seen in hypertension and diabetes.

REFERENCE: ROBBINS & COTRAN pathologic basics of disease, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NUMBER. 493.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old male presents with painless cervical lymphadenopathy, fever, weight loss and night sweats. Biopsy of the lymph node as below:

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Shown picture is of Diagnostic Reed-Sternberg (RS) cell, with two nuclear lobes, large inclusion like nucleoli and abundant cytoplasm.
  1. The presence of Reed-Sternberg cells is characteristic of Hodgkin Lymphoma (HL).
  2. Non Hodgkin Lymphoma (NHL) lacks Reed-Sternberg cells. It has Diffuse or follicular pattern, Lymphoma cells infiltrate and replace normal lymphoid tissue.
  3. Reactive Lymphadenitis would show preserved nodal architecture and no Reed-Sternberg cells.
  4. Metastatic Carcinoma would show malignant epithelial cells.

REFERENCE: ROBBINS & COTRAN pathologic basics of disease, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NUMBER:613.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old male with a history of some mineral dust exposure presents with progressive shortness of breath and bilateral lung crackles. Chest imaging shows bilateral pleural thickening and interstitial fibrosis. Lung biopsy reveals:

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• This a picture of Asbestos body revealing typical beading and knobbed ends.
  • It consists of a central asbestos fiber coated with iron-rich protein material, typically iron and protein from the surrounding lung tissue. This coating gives the appearance of a golden-brown or yellow-brown color under light microscopy.
  • History, clinical symptoms and radiological findings also favors diagnosis of Asbestosis. (option B)

Option A , C and D are incorrect.

REFERENCE: ROBBINS & COTRAN pathologic basics of disease, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NUMBER. 1144.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with a painless testicular mass. Ultrasound reveals a homogeneous, hypoechoic lesion. Gross image is shown. IHC positive for OCT3/4. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The gross image reveals well circumscribed pale, fleshy, homogenous mass which is suggestive of seminoma.

Radiological and IHC for positive OCT3/4 confirms the diagnosis.

Option A. Embryonal Carcinoma: Grayish-white, soft, and friable With Hemorrhagic or necrotic areas.

Option B. Teratoma:

  • Cystic, solid, or mixed appearance
  • Variegated cut surface with different tissue types (e.g., cartilage, bone, hair)
  • May contain fluid-filled cysts

Option D: Torsion of testis presents with Dark discoloration of testis due to hemorrhage and infarction.

REFERENCE: ROBBINS & COTRAN pathologic basics of disease, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NUMBER. 970.

questions.text: What type of cell is this?
questions.solution:
• Picture is of PAP smear. Bacteria are seen in the background, mainly covering the squamous cells resulting in clue cells (arrows).
  • Clue cells are squamous cells covered by coccobacilli with extension to the cell edges (velvety coat or shaggy appearance)
  • Clue cells are a diagnostic hallmark of bacterial vaginosis, indicating the presence of Gardnerella vaginalis and other anaerobic bacteria.

B. Mott cells are plasma cells that have become abnormal due to malignant transformation. They are often seen in:

  1. Multiple myeloma
  2. Plasmacytoma
  3. Lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma

C.Endocervical cells: These cells are derived from the endocervical canal and are typically tall, columnar cells with a small nucleus.

REFERENCE: ROBBINS & COTRAN pathologic basics of disease, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NUMBER. 988.

questions.text: Identify the karyotype shown in the image. Which of the following features are most likely to be seen in this syndrome?
questions.solution:
• The karyotype is 47XXY (KLINEFELTER’S SYNDROME).

Key Features:

  1. Extra X chromosome (47,XXY or mosaic 46,XY/47,XXY)
  2. Male hypogonadism (underactive testes)
  3. Tall stature
  4. Gynecomastia (breast tissue enlargement)
  5. Infertility
  6. Learning disabilities
  7. Social and emotional difficulties

So, option would be A. Gynecomastia and tall stature

B. Webbed neck and short stature:

  • These features are commonly associated with Turner Syndrome (45,X).

C. Simian crease:

  • These feature is commonly associated with Down syndrome(Trisomy 21).

Pedal edema is not a feature of klinefelter syndrome.

REFERENCE: ROBBINS & COTRAN pathologic basics of disease, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NUMBER. 171.

questions.text: Given image of a cell is associated with which of the following condition?
questions.solution:
• Given image is of Pseudo-Pelger-Huet cell.

Pseudo-Pelger-Huet cells are abnormal neutrophils characterized by:

  • Hyposegmented nuclei (<3 lobes)
  • Dysplastic granulopoiesis

B. These cells are commonly seen in Myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS)

  • Myelodysplastic syndromes:
    • Clonal stem cell disorders
    • Dysplasia in ≥1 cell line (erythroid, granuloid, megakaryocytic)
    • Cytopenias (anemia, neutropenia, thrombocytopenia)
    • Risk of transformation to acute myeloid leukemia (AML)

A. Multiple myeloma typically shows Mott cell.

C & D. CLL and ALL are lymphoid neoplasms, whereas Pseudo-Pelger-Huet cells are seen in myeloid disorders.

REFERENCE: ROBBINS & COTRAN pathologic basics of disease, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NUMBER. 621.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old male smoker presents with lung mass. Histopathology shows:

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A. This is an image of invasive adenocarcinoma of lung, acinar type. Irregularly shaped glands are present in fibrotic stroma.

  • Lung adenocarcinoma is the most common type of lung cancer, especially in smokers.
  • Histopathological features:
    • Glandular architecture: Forming gland-like structures
    • Mucin production: Presence of mucin within tumor cells
    • Lepidic pattern: Tumor cells growing along alveolar septa
  • Immunohistochemistry:
    • TTF-1 (thyroid transcription factor 1) positivity supports lung adenocarcinoma.

Option B. Squamous cell carcinoma typically shows keratinization and squamous differentiation.

p63 and CK5/6 positivity suggests squamous cell carcinoma.

Option C: Small cell carcinoma is characterized by small, round, blue cells with neuroendocrine features.

Option D. Large cell carcinoma lacks distinctive differentiation.

REFERENCE: ROBBINS & COTRAN pathologic basics of disease, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NUMBER. 719.

questions.text: What is the primary cause of this lesion shown in the image?
questions.solution:
This is the image of wedge shaped infarct of kidney.

Infarction is a type of tissue damage caused by inadequate blood supply, leading to cellular death. (Localized area of coagulative necrosis)

Thus, Ischemia is the primary cause for the infarction.

  • Ischemia:
    • Reduction or cessation of blood flow
    • Insufficient oxygen and nutrient delivery
    • Accumulation of metabolic waste
  • Ischemia types:
    • Arterial ischemia (e.g., thrombosis, embolism)
    • Venous ischemia (e.g., thrombophlebitis)
    • Hypoxic ischemia (e.g., respiratory failure)
  • Consequences of ischemia:
    • Cellular death (necrosis)
    • Tissue damage (infarction)
    • Organ dysfunction

Option A. Infection: May cause tissue damage, but primary mechanism is microbial invasion.

Option B. Toxicity: Can cause cellular damage, but primary mechanism is chemical injury.

Option D. Autoimmunity: May cause tissue damage, but primary mechanism is immune-mediated.

REFERENCE: ROBBINS & COTRAN pathologic basics of the, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NUMBER. 40.

questions.text:
A liver biopsy from 35-year-old patient shows:

Which of the following mutations is most likely responsible for this?
questions.solution:
• Given image is of Prussian blue stained section, hepatocellular iron appears blue in case of Hereditary hemochromatosis.
  • Hereditary Hemochromatosis (HH) is primarily associated with mutations in the HFE (option A) gene, but other genes can also contribute to the disease.

HFE Gene Mutations:

  1. C282Y: Most common mutation, associated with 80-90% of HH cases.
  2. H63D: Less penetrant mutation, often found in compound heterozygosity with C282Y.

Other Gene Mutations:

  1. TFR2 (Transferrin Receptor 2): Rare mutations associated with juvenile-onset HH
  2. SLC40A1 (Ferroportin): Rare mutations associated with ferroportin disease
  3. HJV (Hemojuvelin): Rare mutations associated with juvenile-onset HH
  4. HAMP (Hepcidin): Rare mutations associated with juvenile-onset HH

Option B. Wilson's Disease: ATP7B gene mutations

Option D. Familial Hypercholesterolemia: LDLR gene mutations

REFERENCE: ROBBINS & COTRAN pathologic basics of disease, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NUMBER. 849
